title: tims-tales-sound-silence
story: I WAS in my favourite wood last weekend: Butterdean. Itrsquos getting busy these days, often with families, which is great to see. Even still there is enough space amidst the trees to quickly find solitudeyou need it.I can never visit this wonderful place without whispering a word of thanks to Gregor Neil Robertson for his role, along with others, in saving this precious and magical wood, which my family has almost literally grown up in.I have got to know Gregor, who still lives in East Lothian, and the world is made a better place by caring and thoughtful people like him.We arrived at the wood in late afternoon, knowing that we wouldnrsquot have a lot of time before nightfall. The ground was literally carpeted with orange and yellow, and autumn colours still hung on the trees.But there was a nip in the air a cold crisp reminder that summer is now long gone and the fingers of winter are about to grip us. So we kept on the move to keep warm.As we ventured deeper into the wood I noticed something. ldquoStop, I said to the kids, ldquoand listen.There was not a breath of wind, it was deathly still. The trees stood in absolute silence. I couldnrsquot even hear any traffic, or the usual distant murmurings of modern day le. There was no noise, only the sound of nature.Bird song was above us. I was surprised to hear such a chorus on a late autumn afternoon.We stood, listening. It was asthe birds were suddenly singing for us, and the children were genuinely enthralled, as was I.We decided to continue our walk, but our mood had now changed. The silence could have been eerie but it wasnrsquot, it heightened our awareness that the wood had le we couldnrsquot see.It was asour inner senses had been aroused. The kids wanted to walk silently, so they could continue to listen. So we practised ldquowalking like a Native American hunter as taught to us by Chris Yule, another East Lothian environmental luminary.We crept through the wood, looking for deer, and faeries, now acutely aware of any faint sound that the absence of noise made possible to hear.Finally we reached our favourite place, and sat, still listening. I have to tell you, seeing my two youngest being so quiet for so long was a unique experience.Then it began to get dark, and the bird song faded away.We headed back to the car as the trees turned into shadows. But we still stopped every now and then to listen and peer into the undergrowth. We were convinced at one point we could see a deer hiding from us.We got to the car as the last glimmering light in the sky vanished, and the moon came out from behind the clouds. It was a magical experience, not a scary one. Wersquod had an unexpected connection with nature, that wasnrsquot visual, but something deeper.I turned the engine on, breaking the silence, and we ed to our world of articial light and constant noise. But the whole walk had had a meditative effect on us, and I reflected on the fact that we are replacing sound with noise, and we are the poorer for that.We are so constantly surrounded by human made sounds that we donrsquot notice it. The noise has become the background to our lives. Few of us probably reflect that we need to connect to the sounds of nature anymore, or true silence itself.Our inner selves do however. Call it what you will, our soul, our spiritual self, our primeval awareness. The truth is we need the absence of noise every now and then so the sounds of nature can be heard. It replenishes us, reminds us who we really are, and lts our mental health. No matter how much we pave nature over with cement, we cannot avoid the fact we are part of it and need it.Yet, we are increasingly separated from it, including the sounds and the silence that comes with the absence of our noise. Is there a connection between this and the mental health crisis we now face The neon lights of a shopping centre, and the constant buzz and noise we fill our everyday lives with may seem like progress, but it isnrsquot for our well being. We need places where such noise is absent ndash where only nature is heard. No, actually, we need many more of these places, but sadly we are going in the reverse direction destroying the ones that survive.

title: cockenzie-family-return-italian-roots-open-food-lovers-paradise
story: They have restored the home of their ancestors in Picinisco in Lazio, Italy, and turned it into a holiday destination complete with a boutique hotel, cookery school and winery.Members of the Di Ciacca family moved to Cockenzie  years ago and Cesido Di Ciacca took over The Cockenzie Cafe, a cafe, fish  chip shop and ice-cream shop, in .The family lived above the shop on  High Street and integrated themselves into the community. Cesido was soon the honorary president of Cockenzie Star football club.The shop stayed in the family and closed in , just before Cesidorsquos son, Johnnie Di Ciacca, died.Johnniersquos own son, who is now  and is also called Cesido, lived in Cockenzie from his birth until he married his we Selina, , in . The couple continued to live in Scotland until  when they started their new business venture in Italy.The last of the Di Ciacca family to live in Picinisco died in  and their hamlet lsquoI Ciaccarsquo had been abandoned ever since.I Ciacca is a small hamlet near the town of Picinisco, Val Comino. The area is a historic region between Rome and Naples.I Ciacca has now been established as an lsquoAlbergo Dfusorsquo, which translates as a lsquoscattered hotelrsquo.Cesido and Selina moved to I Ciacca and began restoring the buildings ahead of opening their boutique hotel, Sotto Le Stelle, in .The same year, the Di Ciacca family started to clear the ground to plant vines at I Ciacca. A vineyard has now been re-cultivated and local farm produce revitalised, enabling the family to bring food, drink and authentic Italian hospitality back to Picinisco.The historic family buildings have also now been restored and turned into the cookery school, winery and further accommodation.This second and final phase of the I Ciacca project was completed in September this year. The hotel, cookery school and winery are now complete and taking bookings for overnight stays, cookery classes and winery vineyard tours.Cesidio Di Ciacca, said: ldquoOne hundred years since leaving to come to Scotland, wersquore immensely proud to be putting Picinisco, Val di Comino, back on the food loversrsquo map with the launch of I Ciacca.ldquoI Ciacca was home to generations of the Di Ciacca family for over  years. By breathing new le into our familyrsquos forgotten hamlet and the town, wersquore now able to offer a new generation of food and wine enthusiasts the chance to experience authentic Italian hospitality in an area of outstanding natural beauty.ldquoOur familyrsquos heritage of quality ice cream, food and hospitality since  in East Lothian is still to be found in Scotland today, including some of the best restaurants, cafes, delicatessens and wine merchants in Edinburgh.ldquoFrom I Ciacca we organise food and wine tours to learn about genuine local foods from pasta, pizza, cheese, prosciutto and other cured meats, to our own olive oil and letrsquos not forget wine ndash especially our very special Maturano.The Di Ciacca family is also working with one of the worldrsquos top winemakers, Alberto Antonini, to produce a new range of speciality organic wines made from their own Maturano grapes ndash a unique iety from Picinisco, almost lost and only recently brought back into commercial cultivation.The Di Ciacca family has just released its Nostalgia IGT Lazio Maturano in Scotland, which is the first time that Maturano wine will be commercially available in the country. It is now available to purchase from Edinburghrsquos Valvona  Crolla.Cesido, his we Selina, and son Giovanni, , now live in Picinisco for most of the year, but still spend time in Scotland. His daughter Sofia, , lives between Edinburgh and Picinisco.Cesidorsquos brother Paul and his cousins Marietta and Laura still live in Cockenzie whilst his sisters are Mary Contini, director of Valvona and Crolla Ltd in Edinburgh, and Carina Contini of Contini George Street, Cannonball Restaurant  Bar, and The Scottish Cafe  Restaurant at the Scottish National Gallery in Edinburgh.

title: charitys-animal-heroes-workshops-memory-meghan-ambrozevich-blair
story: Fostering Compassion is launching Animal Heroes workshops ndash to take place in East Lothian early next year, and also the Borders and Fe ndash in tribute to Meghan Ambrozevich-Blair.The -year-old was killed almost three years ago following a crash on the A between the Spott and Thistly Cross roundabouts, near Dunbar.As part of the charityrsquos initiative, funds will be raised to help save the lives of animals who need resuscitation after being rescued from fires.The Ormiston-based charityrsquos new Animal Heroes Workshops are due to take place at Dunbar Primary School in early .They will be dedicated to Meghan, who is the daughter of East Lothian firefighter and Queenrsquos Fire Service Medal recipient Kevin Blair and his we Lauren.Lesley Winton, CEO of Fostering Compassion, told the Courier: ldquoThe new workshop, which will see the charity teaming up with the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, will teach children about animals who save humans and humans who save animals.ldquoFor the latter part of the workshop, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service will come to talk to the children about amazing animal rescues they have been part of. The children will also learn about fire safety to keep humans and animals safe.Meghan, from Dunbar, was awarded a posthumous First Class Honours degree from Edinburgh Napier University, where she was studying veterinary nursing, following her death in December .In a statement, her mum and dad said: ldquoWe remember Meghan talking about meeting Lesley and how excited she was about the prospect of being involved with Fostering Compassion. The workshop is such a lovely way to keep Meghanrsquos memory alive.Each Fostering Compassion workshop includes the donation of lsquogts of compassionrsquo from the children to animals in need.Through the Animal Heroes workshops, funds will be raised to donate Smokey Paws oxygen mask kits, used by firefighters to resuscitate animals pulled from fires, to each of the  fire stations in the Lothians, Borders and Fe, which do not yet have them.These gts help encourage compassion and empathy in the children and at the same time, with the blessing of her family, will help keep Meghanrsquos memory alive.Miss Winton added: ldquoMeghan was also a firm believer of lsquorandom acts of kindnessrsquo and created the lsquoWishing Treersquo in Pressmennan Woods in East Lothian where she hung inspirational messages full of hope and love. Both these gestures and activities will be incorporated in the workshop and the children will be encouraged to continue them at home to build on positive behavioural changes as a result of attending the Fostering Compassion activities.ldquoThe idea of the Animal Heroes workshop came to me almost four years ago around the time Meghanrsquos and my paths first crossed and she put me in touch with her father. After her devastating accident, I was determined the workshop would come to fruition, but would be done as a tribute to her.ldquoWe are greatly honoured to have her familyrsquos blessing to do this and thank them very much for their unwavering support.Fostering Compassion runs animal and nature-themed workshops for children in foster care and kinship care. Since starting in  with just  children, nearly  youngsters from throughout Scotland have now benefited from the programme.

title: pictures-dunbars-new-bear-sculpture-near-a1-unveiled
story: The renowned Scottish artist created the sculpture in tribute to Dunbar-born John Muir, who went on to play a key role in the formation of the US national park system.The ft sculpture is now sited off the A, near to Dunbarrsquos McDonaldrsquos and Asda.Children from Dunbar Primary School were invited to bring their own bears along to the unveiling of the sculpture todayby Brenda McNeill from Hallhill Developments.The developer has been involved in the construction of more than  houses in the south of the town and the statue has been created through the Percent for Art Scheme, which is a condition of planning consent.The brown bear is symbolic of Muirrsquos travels through the far-off wilderness of Americarsquos west, in the Rockies and Alaska.Like Muir, the bear has travelled from Scotland to America. After Mr Scott was commissioned to create the bear, he moved to the US with his we and the bear travelled over with him.It was brought back to Scotland from his workshop in Philadelphia and was lted by crane to its spot by the A yesterday morning .Mr Scott told the Courier: ldquoIrsquom delighted and relieved that the bear has made it to Dunbar, this was quite a long project coming together and getting it all to happen.ldquoBetween being commissioned and starting the project, my we and I moved to America so I had to take it over there to build it, so hersquos been around the world and itrsquos quite fitting, especially with the legacy of John Muir.ldquoEverybody is really happy with him and I hope he becomes a great success for the town.

title: plans-transport-hub-including-car-park-haddington
story: Following a series of closed door meetings, proposals by East Lothian Council for land next to Whittingehame Drive will be revealed to the public at a drop-in meeting in Haddington Town House on December , -pm.A proposal of applicationnotice for the site, which surrounds the townrsquos skate park and all-weather G sports pitches, was validated by the local authorityrsquos planning department last Wednesday.The simple drawings, which do not give any specic detail, show an area of land stretching from almost the gates at Haddington Golf Club in the south to the River Tyne in the north. The site borders the golf course and St Martinrsquos Cemetery.A formal planning application, which should set out exactly what is planned, is yet to be submitted.The local authority says it wants to create a ldquotransport hub with associated parking spaces and ldquobus connections, bike hire opportunities and new pathways.If approved, this would, says the council, have ldquothe potential to free up parking spaces in the town centre for short-stay use, making it easier for people to access local businesses, essential services and tourist attractions.Work on the project,approved, could begin as early as April next year. The car park would have somewhere between  and  spaces, the Courier has learnt.But some community figures in Haddington have accused the council of keeping people in the dark over the project.Liz McDougall, chairwoman of the Nungate Gala, said: ldquoMy thoughts are it is such a bad move.ldquoIt is going to endanger kidsrsquo lives and I cannot see the relevance in putting the car park down there.ldquoThey would be much better putting it on the other side of the town where they are throwing up houses and a school [at Letham Mains].Mrs McDougall questioned why the early plans had been made public last Wednesday ndash the day after the townrsquos community council meeting ndash when they were listed as being published the day beforehand on the local authorityrsquos planning site.She encouraged as many members of the public as possible to go to the drop-in meeting.Mrs McDougall said: ldquoI will do everything in my power andthat means trawling through the Nungate to get people to sign a petition against it I will."This should not be done.Pat Lemmon, from the townrsquos community council, felt there were a number of questions yet to be answered.She said: ldquoI find it very hard that the plans came in the day after the community council meeting. The timing was bad.The Whittingehame Drive plans come as early-stage proposals have been mooted for a complete revamp of parking in the centre of Haddington, which, as previously reported by the Courier, could see the long-stay car park at the townrsquos Tesco be made short-stay and the loss of up to  parking spaces on High Street and Market Street, a prospect which has concerned some town traders.The Courier submitted a number of written questions to East Lothian Council about the transport hub plans, including whether there would be a charge to use the car park and shuttle buses to the town centre what the projectrsquos cost would be and how it would be funded.The council responded that ldquowork on developing the proposals is still ongoing, adding: ldquoWe will set out more detailed plans in the months ahead, when such information is available.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe local community in Haddington first put forward their ideas in their lsquoVision for Haddington Town Centrersquo back in  and East Lothian Council has been supporting them in delivering their aims which includes lsquoimproving the attractiveness, ality and accessibility of the town in support of the community and local businessesrsquo.ldquoWorking closely with local groups, East Lothian Councilrsquos priorities are to protect and enhance the local environment while supporting the local economy, including town centre retailers and other businesses."The plans are ambitious and seek to create a transport hub with associated parking spaces that addresses climate change through the inclusion of EV chargepoints, bus connections, bike hire opportunities and new pathways."This has the potential to free-up parking spaces in the town centre for short-stay use, making it easier for people to access local businesses, essential services, and tourist attractions during the day."To help develop these proposals the council has secured signicant funding from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Town Centre Fund and has also made an application to the European Regional Development Fund.ldquoA public exhibition, where initial plans can be viewed, is expected to be held before Christmas."Comments received will help to form a full planning application and so itrsquos too early to provide further details at this stage but East Lothian Council remains committed to continuing our engagement with local stakeholders on this initiative and setting out more detailed plans in the months ahead.

title: married-woman-claimed-single-pocket-60-000-benefits
story: Claire Robertson obtained pound, in tax credits from  to  after she informed the authorities she was living at home as a single woman.Robertson, , began the wrongful claim in August  and carried on claiming cash she was not entitled to, under her maiden name of Wells, until March last year.But following an investigation, it emerged Robertson had married her husband in September  and he was earning an income.Robertson, of Dolphingstone View, appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday where she pleaded guilty to obtaining pound, in tax credits she was not entitled to.Prosecutor Heather Carmichael told the court that Robertson had ldquonot advised the tax credit office of her marriage and was claiming the cash as a single person.Ms Carmichael said: ldquoShe was residing with her husband and the tax credits should not have been paid on that basis. Her husbandrsquos income had not been taken into account.The fiscal added ldquothe matter came under investigation and the accused was arrested on March  last year.Police arrived at her home with a search warrant and she was taken to St Leonardrsquos Police Station in Edinburgh.Robertsonrsquos solicitor said his client ldquohad made provisions to pay the money back and stated she should be able to pay the money back to HMRC ldquoas soon as possible.The lawyer said Robertsonrsquos husband worked offshore and was ldquonot always at home.He added that Robertson was willing to remortgage the family property in a bid to pay the money back.Sherf Peter Braid deferred sentence until December  for background reports and a restriction of liberty assessment to be prepared.Robertson admitted wrongly obtaining tax credits amounting to pound, by claiming ndash between August ,  and March  last year ndash she was single with no other income when she was married and her husband was earning a salary.

title: express-service-edinburgh-not-viable-says-bus-company
story: Prestonpans Community Councillors invited Prentice Buses and East Coast Buses to a meeting last Tuesday to discuss the possibility of an express bus service at peak times.This followed a Scottish Transport Appraisal Guidancereport into public transport which highlighted that people living in Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton faced hour-long bus journeys to Edinburgh ndash yet those living . miles further away from the city centre in North Berwick could get a bus to the Capital in just  minutes.But Ian Bieniowski, network performance manager at East Coast Buses, said eventhe company could fill a bus at commuter times, those buses would not cover the running costs of the service.Ross Prentice, owner of Prentice Buses, also attended the meeting.Brian Weddell, community council chair, said: ldquoWe are being treated dferently from the people in North Berwick.ldquoItrsquos not right that you can get into Edinburgh quicker on a bus from North Berwick than Prestonpans.ldquoIrsquom sure you would get the patronage on an express bus at commuter times given the problems with the trains. People are looking for an alternative. Theyrsquore getting into their cars and traffic into Edinburgh is getting busier.Community councillor Gordon Laing said: ldquoI think that the service that we have down here is absolutely dreadful.ldquoWhat you forget with the  [bus] is Seton Sands and in the summertime buses are filled before they even get [to Prestonpans].But Mr Bieniowski said: ldquoEvenwe fill a bus with  people in the morning and  people in the evening, it still needs to cover running costs.ldquoWe do have buses that come out at peak times and then sit in the garage for the rest of the time but we have to minimise the amount of buses that do that. If that happens then itrsquos an asset that is making no money.ldquoAt the moment we donrsquot think it could run commercially as a service. Wersquore not allowed to run it at a loss.ldquoThe reality is thatyoursquore travelling from Prestonpans the fare should be about pound. like it is from South Queensferry but Prestonpans is still within the city limits. North Berwick pay more.Ward councillor Lachlan Bruce askedthere was a reason the company could not charge more for an express service. Mr Bieniowski said that a more expensive express service had been trialled years ago within city limits but had not worked.Mr Prentice added: ldquoThere are more and more pressures coming all the time. title: tims-tales-christmas-conscience
story: THE onset of winter, with the deadly cold and dark, was something John always dreaded.It was at this time he would make the decision to line up for a place for a hostel bed.John was homeless and he usually slept rough. Hersquod not always been homeless, of course, but people rarely see the person behind the label.The one good thing about winter for him was the approach of Christmas. Peoplersquos consciences seemed to be more sensitive at Christmas time.He was an alcoholic and he blamed himself every day for what he was. But this just fed his sense of worthlessness and kept the cycle going. His earlier le, the lsquonormal onersquo with his we and children, was now a long time ago, but when he slumbered he often re-entered it in his dreams.Especially that last family Christmas, when they were all together. He would re-run that time in his mind, just like his we would watch The Devil Wears Prada over and over and never tire of it. Yes, when he closed his eyes it could seem he was there again.But when he came to his senses, he came back to himself: an unloved man, old before his time, who people ignored and passed in the street without looking at. He usually felt completely invisible. To be fair, some people did stop and talk, usually the same ones.Perhaps they never truly understood just how valued those moments were.He understood it, after all he despised himself, so how could he expect others to feel dferently.Alcohol seemed to be his one real friend, the only one to understand and ease his pain.But St Andrewrsquos Day was approaching and this was his cue to get completely sober.He would feel that tingle inside that people call lsquofeeling Christmassyrsquo. It was a painful, bittersweet emotion for John, and his friend alcohol always offered to help. But he would close his eyes and be strong.It was the one thing in his le where he felt he had not let people down.So he would summon all his strength and draw on who he used to be for those last vestiges of self-belief and refuse the offer of help from his destructive friend.He made it and arrived at the door of the managerrsquos office, clean, sober and ready to work.The manager had no idea John was the same man he passed on a daily basis on the street outside.Admittedly, he did look dferent now, butthe manager had ever paused to look at John or speak to him, then he would surely recognise him. But for once he was glad of his invisibility. If the manager had ever recognised him outside then John would probably lose his job.ldquoYour costume is in the back room. You start in  minutes, said the manager.ldquoThe paperwork came through last week so yoursquore set to go.John knew the routine and got changed.When he sat in his chair, he was transformed. He was Santa.For the next five weeks, he knew he was going to be noticed and even loved. People would speak to him in a kind and almost reverent way, ask him how he was. His beard and red suit wiped away his sense of worthlessness.All that day, families came and he spoke to more people in that one day being Santa than he did the rest of the year being himself.Afterwards, he headed back to the hostel with money in his pocket.His old friend whispered in his ear: ldquoSpend it on me, spend it on me.ldquoMaybe later, but not now, John replied in his head.But the hostel was full and he couldnrsquot find any other place.And so he knew hersquod have to spend a bitter night on the streets.The food van would arrive soon, so he decided to wait for it in the busy centre.As he sat, a young girl came up to him.She just stood and stared. John recognised her.She had been one of the children in his grotto earlier and suddenly a fear gripped him: she might recognise who he really was.ldquoCome away from there, shouted her mother.But the girl still stood, staring at John. Then she smiled. John smiled back.Her father came up and took her by the hand, pulling her away without looking at John.He recognised the father as well.He had been so nice and friendly in the grotto, while his daughter stood with him for a photo.But without his white beard and red suit, John was invisible again.ldquoSpend it on me, spend on me, whispered his old friend again, as John had flashbacks of Afghanistan.ldquoSpend it on me and I will keep you company, nobody  cares, pleaded his friend.Then the girl was in front of him again, smiling.ldquoThis is for you, Merry Christmas when it comes.Her father stood by her, holding her hand, but still not looking at John.It was chocolate. The same chocolate bar shersquod chosen with glee in the grotto.ldquoThank you, said John and the girl left with her dad.Johnrsquos old friend was now silent. The food van arrived and he packed the chocolate under his jacket. It was more than chocolate.Now he had to get through the freezing night.Tomorrow, hersquod be loved again.

title: celebrating-pls-home-50-years

title: chance-help-fund-community-projects-preston-seton-gosford
story: Everyone over the age of eight, who lives in the Preston Seton Gosford area, can votefor projects to recieve a portion of the funding fromthe Heritage Lottery and the Preston Seton Gosford Area Partnership which is supported by East Lothian Council.The community were asked to put forward ideas for projects which will have a positive impact in promoting local heritage and benefit the communities of Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton, and Longniddry.Nineteen projects submitted applications.Voting will take place todayat Prestonpans Community Centre .pm-pm.Tomorrowat Port Seton community Centre .pm- pm.And Thursdaypm-pm at Longniddry Community Centre pm-pm.There will be a final chance to vote on Wednesday  December, pm-pm at Preston Lodge High School.Representatives from each project will have a chance to pitch to voters at this event and they will be there to answer questions. title: tims-tales-wise-old-witch
story: HAPPY St Andrewrsquos Day! The results of a poll on peoplersquos favourite Scots word by Scottish Book Trust was revealed this week.So herersquos a tale that includes all the top  favourite Scots words identied in the poll, plus some mair:THE weather matched the young wersquos mood: dreich.By the time she reached the witchrsquos cottage at the foothills of the Lammermuirs, she was soaked.ldquoOch, come in hen, ye look drookit, said the old woman sympathetically. They sat by the fire together.ldquoNoo how can I help ye  asked the old woman.The young we sighed.ldquoI just cannae thole it onymair, she said, getting upset.The old woman listened, waiting for the young woman to compose herself.ldquoItrsquos ma mither-in-law, she bides wi us and, weel, shersquos makin ma le a misery.ldquoHow sae  asked the old woman.ldquoI can dae naethin richt accordin tae her ma cookin is awfu, my hoose is mingin, I canne gie an opinion aboot onythin withoot her sayin the opposite, she treats me asIrsquom glaikit. Irsquom totally scunnerd wi it.ldquoI see, said the witch, ldquoand how can I help ye wi this ldquoI want her oot ma le, I want her deid.ldquoDeid  The witch seemed genuinely shocked.ldquoAye, deid, gone, awa. I just want her oot ma hoose and oot ma le.ldquoWeel, she doenae hae tae be deid fir that, suggested the witch.ldquoAye she does, I dinnae want her aroond. Shersquoll come knocking oan the door. Please can ye help me. I want her deid... er, wi oot it, ye ken, weel sae it isnae murder.ldquoBut it wud be murder ma dear.The young woman bent her head low and began to whisper assomeone might overhear their conversation.ldquoI ken, but ye are a witch, abody says ye hae potions fir onything. Please, I have siller. Mak it look natural. Then me an ma husband can get oan wi oor lives thegither.The witch thought for a moment, then nodded her head.ldquoVery weel, I will help ye, but ye maun dae whit I say.The we smiled with relief: ldquoThank ye.The old woman went ben the hoose to where she kept her herbs and ingredients. The young woman was curious and tried to sneak a look but the witch told her to stay by the fireside until she was finished.Then she came through holding a small bottle of potion.ldquoHere, she said to the we. ldquoThis will dae the trick. Ye maun put ane sma drap o this potion in yer mither-in-lawrsquos tea every day.ldquoBut she maks her ain tea, said the young woman, ldquoshe ay complains I cannae mak tea the proper way.ldquoWeel, ye maun find a way fir her tae allow ye tae mak her tea, said the witch. ldquoThen every day sit wi her as she drinks the tea. She maun drink it a.The we smiled: ldquoHow lang will it tak ldquoOch, mebbes twa months, ye maun use up the hale bottle. Then it will tak effect a few days ater the last drap has been drunk.ldquoTwa months!ldquoAye hen, it must be gradual, otherwise folk will suspect.The young woman clutched the bottle and nodded.ldquoNoo can I hae the siller, asked the witch, and the we willingly paid.ldquoMind tae gie the bottle a wee shoogle afore ye yaise it, the witch advised, ldquoand hud yer wheesht aboot this, or wersquoll baith hang.ldquoO course, said the young woman as she left the witchrsquos house.The weather had lted, as had her mood. Soon her problems would be over, she thought to herself.The witch watched her go, then closed the door. She had a knowing grin on her face.Two months later there was a desperate knocking on the old womanrsquos door. She looked out of the window and saw the young we standing just outwith the cottage, in a terrible state.So she opened her door.ldquoPlease, please help me, begged the young woman.The witch took her inside. The young woman had run all the way and her shawl had become wrapped round her hair, and her dress was dishevelled with the wind.ldquoOch hen, ye are in a richt fankle, sort yersel oot and sit by the fire fir a warm.The young we rearranged her clothes and started to greet as she spoke.ldquoHae ye got an antidote fir the potion please say ye huv, she said.ldquoAn antidote, hen ldquoAye, Irsquove changed ma mind. I gied ma mither-in-law a cup of tea wi the last drap o potion. I watched her drink and then she telt me that I mak a braw cup of tea and that she wis glad her son hud marrit me! It wis in that moment I realised I didnae want her deid!ldquoI see, said the witch. ldquoIrsquom afraid there is nae antidote fir the potion.The young women cradled her head in her hands. ldquoWhit huv I done, what huv I done, she cried to herself.ldquoYe huv got tae ken her, thatrsquos whit yersquove done, said the witch. ldquoAs ye spent time wi her making sure she drank her tea, ye will have talked, am I richt ldquoAye, sobbed the we, ldquoand she listened tae. I ken shersquos an auld witch sometime, er nae offence, but I understand her better noo.The witch smiled. ldquoGuid, she said, ldquonoo ye can gang hame and keep oan huvin the tea thegither, without the potion.ldquoBut shersquos goanie be deid in a few days, sobbed the we.ldquoNaw she isnae, replied the witch, ldquothe potion wis just a few herbs that wouldnae hairm even a wee beastie.ldquoWhat  Ye telt me that it would kill her! protested the we.ldquoNo I didnae, I said it would work ater twa months. And it has. It wis the hatred ye hud that needed kilt, no yer mither-in-law. And the same goes fir her.The young we was so relieved. For a moment she wondered about asking for her money back, but she realised the potion had indeed done its job.Her relationship with her mother-in-law was not always easy, but they had regular cups of tea and chats together, and often they would laugh as they shared memories and stories from le.ldquoThe claes are in a richt bumfle, said the mother-in-law the following day, then she smiled. ldquoBut letrsquos hae oor tea first and we can sort the claes thegither.The we thought to herself that the witch was indeed a wise woman.

title: mark-smith---trend-bring-dominic-raab-ian-blackford
story: Will any of it happen though  Well, donrsquot discount it because therersquos unpredictable stuff going on in this election that means we could get some major upsets. One of those at risk is Mr Raab, the Brexiter who didnrsquot understand how important Dover is to trade, and the man, too, who said people use foodbanks not because theyrsquore poor but because they have ldquocash-flow problems. The under-currents also make Scottish seats like Mr Blackfordrsquos just as hard to predict.The reason for the unpredictably is a trend in politics that started in earnest in the s but has now reached its apotheosis. In , after a  start in , Labour won the General Election thanks in a large part to tactical voting and itrsquos been a signicant factor in elections ever since. The Tories did well in Scotland in the last General Election, for example, because so many voters chose to vote tactically against the SNP.:SNPrsquos Ian Blackford has a great deal to answer for ndash Lord Menzies CampbellLooking at the polls, this tactical voting trend is going to be even more important this year. According to polling by the Electoral Reform Society,  per cent of voters plan to vote tactically to thwart a candidate they donrsquot like, although itrsquos amazing the figure isnrsquot much higher. Theresa May would have won a majority in just .% of voters had acted dferently, and this time round, the result will come down to a couple of hundred thousand people. If enough of them vote tactically, Boris Johnson wonrsquot get his majority.Over the years, it looks like more and more voters have started to understand this and wersquore now at the point where tactical voting is almost like a political party of its own. It has led to weird sights such as the former Tory minister Michael Heseltine standing behind a LibDem podium and the former Blair PR man Alastair Campbell saying ldquodonrsquot vote Labour! . There are also any number of tactical voting websites that will tell you how to achieve your aim.And it appears to be starting to work. In , Dominic Raab won Esher and Walton with nearly  per cent of the vote andthe national polls were replicated in the seat on December , he would easily win again. However, the current polling in his seat puts the Tories on %, just five per cent ahead of the LibDems. Perhaps Remainers in the constituency who are still wondering whether they should switch should listen to Alastair Campbell: Donrsquot vote Labour!:Harry Dunn: Dominic Raab booed and branded a coward as he leaves hustingsTactical voting is just as important, albeit more complicated, in Scotland, and therersquos evidence that the voters, and the parties, are willing to use it. In recent days ndash much to the amazement and disgust of some ndash support for the Conservatives in Scotland has been rising at the same time itrsquos been falling in England and the explanation has to be that some Unionist voters are choosing the Tories as a tactical vote against the SNP.Therersquos also been evidence of tactical thinking where in Scotland. In Ian Blackfordrsquos seat, for example, therersquos been suspicion that some of the candidates are working to an official pact to maximise voting for the LibDems, and the LibDemsrsquo private polling shows itrsquos having an effect. Some voters may also be unable to resist the chance to take a big SNP scalp in the way they did with Alex Salmond in  .What makes the whole thing much more complicated in Scotland is the way that Brexit and independence intersect. For tactical voting to have any serious effect on the SNP, it requires LibDems and some Labour supporters to switch to the Tories, which many of them did in . But will they be willing to do it again this time, now that the Tories are run by hard Brexiters like Boris Johnson  I suspect a lot of Scottish voters would rather die in a ditch.But the incentive for a big, central group of Scottish voters to behave tactically remains strong. Indeed, the evidence of tactical thinking in Scottish politics underlines a comforting fact about us: there is a still a strong, liberal, progressive, anti-nationalistic centre of voters in Scotland who are just as repulsed by Ian Blackfordrsquos Scottish nationalism as they are by Dominic Raabrsquos British version.If the world was dferent of course, and we were freed of the threats of Brexit and independence , many,not most, of these sensible centrist Scottish voters would support Labour or the LibDems. Certainly, by any realistic, liberal, progressive test, the LibDem manesto wins hands down.However, thatrsquos not the world wersquore stuck with, sadly, which leaves many centrist Scottish voters with an ugly dilemma, especially in seats that will be won either by the Tories or the SNP. Many of the tactical voting guides suggest voting SNP to beat Brexit-supporting Tories, but that misunderstands the subcutaneous trends in modern Scottish politics ndash many Scottish voters do not want Brexit but they do not want independence either. Ideally, they would vote to keep the SNP out of Scottish seats and the Tories out of power at Westminster, but in many constituencies, the system simply does not allow voters to support that option.:SNPs vetting process frustrated by senior MP prior to candidate selectionIn the end, the result of the election will depend on what this group of voters decides to do in Scotland, and what Remainers decide to do in the rest of the UK, but, with Labour support up in England and the Tories up in Scotland, the trend in the polls would seem to suggest that many are already choosing the tactical option. Nicola Sturgeonrsquos pronouncement that a vote for the SNP is a vote for a second Scottish referendum, as well as polls suggesting a Tory majority, may also concentrate the minds of potential tactical voters.And just think of the potential prize on election nightvoters do take the tactical option. .am. Dominic Raab is defeated in Esher and Walton. A little while later, Ian Blackford loses Ross, Skye and Lochaber. It may not happen ndash therersquos a good chance it wonrsquot ndash but the schadenfreude-laden possibility may just be enough for some tactical voters to say: yes, letrsquos do this!

title: labour-genuinely-idiotic-snp-deal-says-better-together-chief
story: Blair McDougall, a Blairite, said Jeremy Corbyns party had accepted what he called the Scottish nationalist premise that politics was about place rather than ideas.Asked about Nicola Sturgeon propping up a Labour government after this months general election, Mr McDougall said: "Its like sitting on a branch and doing a deal with the guy who is sawing the branch. Its crazy. It makes no sense.":Mark Smith: Lets do this - the trend that could bring down Dominic Raab and Ian BlackfordSpeaking to The Times, Mr McDougall piled scorn on London leftwingers who equated Scottish independence with anti-colonial struggles. He said: "The left leadership of the party view this through their anti-imperialist worldview where any national struggle, from Papua New Guinea to Costa Rica, must be part of some historical meta-narrative about resistance and struggle."Such a worldview, he added, was undermining arguments for socialist solidarity from Scottish Labour Richard Leonard. "That belief in solidarity is completely undone by a national leadership who are unable to make that argument because I am not sure they believe in it," he said.Mr McDougall ran for Labour in the last general election, coming third in East Renfrewshire, behind the SNP and the winning Tory.Those two parties, he said,are now in a symbiotic relationship based on identity politics, "Every discussion about politics and policy is about where that decision is made and not about what that decision is," he argued. "And that has been terribly to the detriment of the country.":Nato Secretary General responds to Sturgeons desire to scrap nuclear weaponsUnlike other Blairites, he said he intends to stay in the party, despite anti-semitism rows which have hurt its campaign in East Renfrewshire.He said: "All of our Jewish activists have left. All of them. It is quite tough to square that."

And itrsquos always nice to see the staff having a chat and a laugh with the guests, and similarly neighbouring tables chatting to each other .So come on down to this new hidden gem and see what all the fuss is about!The Prancing StagA Ashwood Gardens | Jordanhill | GLASGOW G NXwww.theprancingstagInstagram @ThePrancingStag

title: un-chief-urges-nations-not-fiddle-planet-burns
story: In his opening speech to delegates, Mr Guterres cited recent scientic data showing that levels of heat-trapping gases have hit a record high, reaching levels not seen for at least three million years when sea levels were - metres higher than today.Unless emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases are sharply cut, temperatures could rise to twice the threshold set in the  Paris accord by the end of the century, he warned.:Sperm Whale washed up on Scottish beach had kg litter ball in stomachldquoDo we really want to be remembered as the generation that buried its head in the sand, that fiddled while the planet burned  Mr Guterres asked.His appeal came after Chilersquos environment minister, Carolina Schmidt, said the December - meeting needs to lay the groundwork for moving toward carbon-neutral economies while being sensitive to the poorest and those most vulnerable to rising temperatures, something that policymakers have termed ldquojust transition.ldquoThose who donrsquot want to see it will be on the wrong side of history, said Ms Schmidt, who is chairing the meeting.She called on governments to make more ambitious pledges to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases ahead of a deadline to do so next year.The summit, which moved to the Spanish capital after Chile had to pull out amid anti-government protests, aims to put the finishing touches to the rules governing the  Paris accord.That involves creating a ing international emissions-trading system and compensating poor countries for losses they suffer from rising sea levels and other consequences of climate change.ldquoWe have a common challenge but with dferentiated needs and urgencies, which we can only overcomewe work together, said Ms Schmidt.Countries agreed in Paris four years ago to limit global warming to well below C , ideally .Cby the end of the century compared with pre-industrial times.Already, average temperatures have increased by about C, leaving little room for the more ambitious target to be met.Mr Guterres called out big greenhouse gas emitters that are still building coal-fired power plants, saying that unless the world stops burning coal ldquoall our efforts to tackle climate change will be doomed.He noted that had countries started cutting their emissions drastically a decade ago, reaching the Paris goal would have been much easier.ldquoTen years ago,countries had acted on the science, they would have needed to reduce emissions by .% each year, he said.ldquoToday, we need to reduce emissions by .% each year.ldquoThe impact on all le on the planet, including ours, would be catastrophic, he added.ldquoThe only solution is rapid, ambitious, transformative action by all mdash governments, regions, cities, businesses and civil society, all working toward a common goal.Organisers expect around , visitors at the meeting, including around  heads of state and government for Mondayrsquos opening session.In contrast to the European Union, which sent its newly sworn-in executive leadership team to the summit, the rest of the worldrsquos largest carbon emitters, the United States, China and India, have sent lower-level ministers and officials.The US sent a delegation, led by Ambassador Marcia Bernicat, a senior State Department official, even though President Donald Trump has formally begun the process of pulling the country out of the Paris accord.However, that wonrsquot be technically completed until November  .But Democratic members of Congress led by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the nation remains committed to the  agreementrsquos goals and that climate change poses a threat to public health, the economy and national security.ldquoWersquore still in it, Ms Pelosi said.:EU parliament declares climate rsquoemergencyrsquo in symbolic moveAsked about comments by Spainrsquos interim prime minister, Pedro Sanchez, that ldquoonly a handful of fanatics deny the evidence of man-made global warming, Ms Pelosi responded that she had ldquothree words that describe how we address this: science, science and science. And maybe four: science, again.ldquoIf we can stick with the science, I think we can come up with some sane solutions to it all, she said.In an interview with The Associated Press, the UN chief hoped that stricter goals in Europe would allow EU leaders to convince fellow big polluters ldquoto understand that this must be a collective effort and that they all will have to correct their policies in order to drastically be able to reduce the emissions

title: herald-diary-dugs-drama-queen
story: PREVIOUS generations of youngsters have kept themselves occupied kicking footballs and nursing dolls. Those pastimes are of little interest to the sophisticated youth of today. Reader Gary McAllon spied his -year-old son studying his iPad feverishly. Father was curious to know what rewarding Internet entertainment son was viewing. ldquoThe best thing ever! explained the lad, pointing to the screen. Playing was something called the lsquoVoice-Crack Compilationrsquo, hundreds of video clips of peoplersquos voices wobbling or breaking while they talked. ldquoMy son had been watching for an hour, groans Gary. ldquoItrsquos certainly not my idea of cracking entertainment.Boomer-rang or right MESSING about in her garden with a boomerang, reader Jenner Caven thought shersquod forgotten how to throw the thing properly. ldquoBut then it came back to me, she adds.Brought to bookCHRISTMAS. A time for faking childish delight whilst tearing open packages filled with stuff wersquod never buy for ourselves. At least Brian Ferguson wonrsquot face any surprises on December th. ldquoMy family always get me the Guinness Book of Records, he says. ldquoFor the rest of December I pretend to read it, even though itrsquos not much dferent from last yearrsquos volume. Brian says his ambition is to appear in next yearrsquos tome. ldquoSurely I must have broken the record for owning the greatest number of unread Guinness Books accumulated under one roof, he boasts.Dog day afternoonWITH the panto season in full swing there will be a lot of heavy-duty ham acting for theatregoers to endure. Which reminds us of this story that appears in the recently released Herald Diary book by Ken Smith.Lucy Freeman was out for a walk when she observed a Labrador in the river, appearing to struggle. As it whimpered, Lucy drew the attention of the dogrsquos owner to this worrying spectacle. The owner, not unduly concerned, said: ldquoHersquos always doing this. Bloody drama queen. Joe! Put your feet down! On this command the Labrador looked sheepish and stood uphellip in water barely reaching his knees.Cold comfortACTRESS Elle Newlands was raised in Scotland though now plies her trade in LA . Late at night, when she canrsquot sleep, she likes to go for a stroll. ldquoTherersquos something about the quiet rhythm of the world in the dead of night that makes sense to me, she whispers rather poetically. Elle then adds in a more down to earth tone that every Scot will identy with: ldquoAnd when itrsquos cold and wet and my lungs wake up, it feels like home.Water silly ideaDAFT joke time. Reader Colin Wright tells us scientists have just invented a new pill that cures dehydration. ldquoAll you have to do is take it three times a day, along with a glass of water, explains Colin.

title: gas-supply-restored-within-two-days-relieved-residents-told
story: Around , properties in the Falkirk area were affected by an equipment failure on Sunday morning, leaving them without gas for heating and cooking.Support centres were set up in Stenhousemuir and Bainsford by the council and electric hotplates and heaters were distributed to vulnerable families and iniduals. Libraries offered residents a place to shelter from freezing temperatures and leisure centres run by Falkirk Community Trust said anyone could come and use their showers for free.Fourteen Schools and nurseries across the area were closed on Monday, but Falkirk Council said all but three ndashwould reopen on Tuesday. Those still unable to open are Bainsford Primary School and Nursery Class, Kinnaird Primary and Larbert Early Learning Centre.The problem was blamed on the failure of equipment used to manage pressure in the gas network. While engineers repaired this quickly, gas infrastructure company SGN had initially warned turning supplies back on safely could take until Friday or even the weekend. But by Monday evening, supplies were being restored to homes across Bainsford, Carron, Carronshore, Larbert, Langlees, New Carron Village, Skinflats and Stenhousemuir.SGN said the revised timescale was due ldquoincredible efforts from our engineers over the past  hours.Despite this, efforts were continuing to ensure the safety of vulnerable people last night and many residents decamped to stay with relatives or friends rather than remain in unheated homes as temperatures dropped.SGN set up an information point at Camelon Community Centre. The company added: ldquoWersquore still providing electric hotplates and heaters for people with young children, a disability, a long-term mental or physical condition or who are a bit older.Meanwhile the regionrsquos libraries offered those affected a place to spend the day. Falkirk Library Trust tweeted: ldquoFalkirk Libraries are open, warm and free. You can sit in any library for as long as wersquore open-no pressure to do anything. You donrsquot need to be a member... Some libraries have drinks machines,not, bring one in. Bring the kids!The company said engineers needed to visit inidual homes to ensure appliances were safe before they could be reconnected. SGN said in a statement: ldquoOur engineers will be revisiting each affected property to reconnect your gas supply, which involves carrying out safety checks. Itrsquos important you donrsquot try to turn on your gas supply yourself. We have more than , properties to visit and it will take us a couple of days to reach everyone.ldquoWersquore prioritising those most vulnerable members of the community first but wersquoll be making every effort to get gas back on to everyonersquos homes as soon as possible.With many homes relying on electricity,they could, as a substitute fuel, power network company SP Energy Networks said it was concerned about increased demand in the area and engineers were monitoring usage.ldquoElectric heaters and hotplates use a lot more power than their gas equivalents, ldquo the company said. ldquoWith this in mind wersquod ask that everyone in the area thinks smart about using electricity just now ndash heat the rooms yoursquore using, wrap up warm and donrsquot have all your devices turned on at once.The company added: ldquoPlease remember to always check the ID of anyone calling at your home. All our engineers carry photo ID badges, as do other official organisations.Local businesses were also affected. The Malcolm Allan butchers in Larbert had to stop production at the bakery where it makes steak pies after losing its gas supply on Monday morning. Director Gordon Allan said: ldquoWersquove staff to pay and wersquore not producing, itrsquos not looking good at all. Itrsquos a major incident, we donrsquot know when it will be sorted and this is a busy time of year for us because we do lots of steak pies for new year.Forth Valley Police said it expected relief efforts to conclude on Tuesday evening, and also appealed to homeowners and tenants to be careful who they gave access to. A spokesman added: ldquoThe public are urged to be a good neighbour and check in on anyone they think may be facing dficulties right now.

title: unveiled-vision-8000-seat-indoor-arena-edinburgh
story: Lothian Leisure Development Ltdhas announced a partnership with Birmingham-based NEC Group to create the ,-capacity venue on a site at Straiton on the outskirts of the city.They plan to transform the -acre site with conference, retail and leisure space, a cinema and two hotels, as well as the arena itself.NEC Group, which already operates two indoor arenas in Birmingham, is supporting LLD as they progress the scheme proposals to "full feasibility stage" and will take on full management of the arena once planning permissions are in place.Dave Fowler, business development director at LLD, said: "These exciting proposals showcase the modern indoor arena that Edinburgh deserves and with operating partner NEC on board the capital is assured a pipeline of the worlds greatest entertainment talent."We also look forward to applying many of the other aspects of the hugely successful NEC Campus to Edinburgh in due course."We see this as a revolution in entertainment provision for one of the worlds most cultural capitals - and one which will benefit all sections of the community."LLD is in discussions with several parties to secure funding for the development phase of the project.It is hoped a planning application will be submitted by the end of .Phil Mead, arenas and ticket factory chairman at NEC Group, said: "Edinburgh is well known for its wonderful cultural offering but remains one of the only European capital cities without an indoor arena and so were excited by the thought of being able to bring some big names in entertainment to the region."Event and concert promoters welcomed the news.Dave McGeachan from DF Concerts said: "These days it is rare that a capital city doesnt have an arena so this is a long awaited and positive addition to the Scottish entertainment market."Mark Mackie from Edinburgh-based Regular Music said: "A venue offering audience capacities between , to , will dovetail nicely with the existing facilities in Edinburgh and Glasgow."We eagerly await the opening when we look forward to presenting a ied range of artists."

title: elon-musk-faces-defamation-trial-twitter-spat-british-diver
story: The Tesla CEO will be called to testy early in the case in Los Angeles federal court to explain what he meant when he called Vernon Unsworth - who helped rescue youth soccer players trapped underwater in a Thailand cave - "pedo guy" in a Twitter spat more than a year ago.Mr Musk later apologised for lashing out at Mr Unsworth on Twitter after the er belittled Mr Musks efforts to build a tiny submarine to save the trapped boys as a "PR stunt". The tweet, widely interpreted as a reference to a paedophile, was removed by Mr Musk, who disputed thats what he meant."Pedo guy was a common insult used in South Africa when I was growing up," Musk said in a court declaration. "It is synonymous with creepy old man and is used to insult a persons appearance and demeanour.":Billionaire Elon Musk apologises for Thai rescue er lsquopedo guyrsquo slurMr Unsworths lawyers have laughed off that explanation and said his claim was undercut by a subsequent tweet when he said, "Bet ya a signed dollar its true", in response to a question about whether he had accused Mr Unsworth of being a paedophile.The lawyers also said he hired private investigators to dig up evidence Mr Unsworth was a child molester, which they never found, according to Mr Unsworths lawyers.The lawsuit is not the first time Mr Musks tweets have landed him in hot water.Mr Musk and Tesla reached a  million settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission last year on allegations he misled investors with a tweet declaring he had secured financing to buy out the electric car maker. He agreed in the settlement to have future tweets about the company screened.He was forced back into court on accusations he violated that agreement by tweeting a misleading figure about how many cars Tesla would manufacture this year.The SEC sought to hold him in contempt of court, which led to a new agreement imposing tighter controls on Mr Musks tweets about the company.The cave drama played out for more than two weeks in the summer of  when the  boys - ages - - and their soccer coach were trapped in a flooded cave in northern Thailand.Mr Musk and engineers from his SpaceX rocket company custom built a mini-submarine to help with the rescue. The device was heavily publicised but never used.Mr Unsworth, a er and caving expert whose advice was considered crucial in the rescue operation, said the sub would never have fit in the caves tight spaces. He told CNN that Mr Musk could "stick his submarine where it hurts".Mr Musk responded two days later with his series of tweets.Mr Musk claims he wasnt making a factual statement and no one reading his tweet would take it seriously and interpret it as defamatory.Despite removing the tweets, he later suggested in emails to the news website BuzzFeed that Mr Unsworth was a "child rapist" and had moved to northern Thailand to take "a child bride who was about  years old at the time". He provided no evidence.Mr Unsworth is seeking unspecied damages for pain, suffering and emotional distress.The defence has resisted efforts to turn over financial records to show Mr Musks wealth but has stipulated his net worth exceeds  billion .

title: inverurie club marks decade of success
story: Inverurie Loco Works Football Club has once again celebrated the very best of business that the North East has to offer with its th annual Business Lunch, sponsored by CALA Homes.Held at The Marclfe Hotel in Aberdeen on Friday, November , the event is one of the most popular events on the North East business calendar.It celebrated it’s tenth consecutive year with theof guest speaker Lady Michelle Mone OBE, following her appearance at the very first Loco Works Business Lunch a decade ago.Lady Mone shared stories of her rise from humble Glasgow-raised bra-designer to a global entrepreneur, and tales of her international business journey.Leading homebuilder CALA Homes was on board once again as the headline sponsor of the  event, as part of its long standing support of the Scottish Highland Football Leagueclub.Mike Naysmith, Managing Director at CALA Homes, commented: “We were thrilled to be able to support the Loco Works Business Lunch as it celebrated  years of bringing Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire’s brightest business minds together.“We’ve supported the club for a number of years and it’s a pleasure to continue our close links with the team and the town of Inverurie.”Vice Chairman and event organiser at the club, Graeme Hay, added: “We pulled out of all the stops to mark ten years of our business lunch and we’re delighted to see it was a huge success.“I’d like to thank Lady Mone for ing to mark the occasion with some truly inspiring stories, CALA Homes for supporting the event and everyone who attended to make the day memorable.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: kintore firm marks 20th anniversary
story: A north-east firm has held a family fun day to celebrate  years in business.eBlast, part of the eGroup, welcomed around  people of all ages to its Kintore headquarters at the Midmill Industrial Estate to help mark the anniversary.Since first opening its doors at the former Inverurie loco works in  with only four employees and a forklt truck, the business has evolved to become one of the largest specialist coatings and surface preparation businesses in the UK and an expert in specialist coatings for extreme environments.Over the past two decades, eBlast has largely focused on meeting the needs of customers in the energy sector with clients ranging from local fabricators to major suppliers to the oil and gas, renewables and construction industries.Speaking at the event Neil McDonald, CEO and chairman of eGroup, proudly commented: “Our people are what has made the company successful and I would like to thank them all for their level of service, reliability and commitment to our clients, which is second-to-none.“It’s their passion which has undoubtedly driven the business forward to this landmark th anniversary.”In , eBlast and its sister companies amalgamated to form the eGroup and provide an integrated service that combines commercial and industrial coating, painting and surface preparation with structural steel fabrication, cladding installation and non-destructive testingservices, among other specialisms.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Eilish enjoys lunch with pupils from Oyne Primary School"  Olympian inspires Oyne pupils viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: olympian inspires oyne pupils
story: Pupils at Oyne Primary had a special visitor last month as Scottish Olympian and Commonwealth athlete Eilish McColgan spent a morning with pupils, staff and parents.The visit on Friday, November  was organised by Active Schools Aberdeenshire and supported by local business Logie Country House, and arranged through the “Champions In Scotland” programme.The Dundee-born runner spoke to pupils from P to P about her career so far and focused on how pupils could achieve their “personal best”.She led a short session of dynamic warms ups and one of the highlights of the morning was a question and answer session, which included some parents with children at the school.Questions ranged from her favourite event so far, which was the  Olympics in London, her motivation to keep running faster and an overview of her training, diet and sleep routine, all aimed at achieving her “personal best” whenever she competes for Scotland or Great Britain.Pupils also got to see some of her medal collection, with last year’s European Championship Silver in the m in Berlin being a standout, and the experience for the pupils was made even better when Eilish joined them for school lunch.Eilish also met Stef and Tim Erbe, who as the owners of Logie Country House have supported the extra-curricular programme at Oyne Primary School this school year, which includes a jogging club.Before heading home to begin her preparations for the Olympics in Japan next summer, Eilish also had time to visit Inverurie Academy, where she met a class of S pupils. They also took the chance to have a question and answer session and have an Olympic athlete give them some coaching tips. Active Schools Lead Coordinator for Central Aberdeenshire, Malcolm Grant, said: “Across Scotland this month the sporting theme from sportscotland is Local Heroes and Eilish ticked every box during her visits to Oyne Primary and Inverurie Academy. “The focus on personal best resonates strongly across a broad range of school subjects, not just sport, but having Eilish presenting her thoughts on her own career and how she intends to continue to improve and progress, despite her already extensive achievements in athletics, ensured that all of the pupils went home with some extra inspiration and motivation to do the best that they can, whatever they choose to do in the future.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Neil McDonald, Scott Duguid and Peter Taylor at the eBlast celebration event"  Kintore firm marks th anniversaryviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Lady Michelle Mone OBE attended the Inverurie Loco Works Football Club Business Lunch"  Inverurie club marks decade of success viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: retail plans at former health centre site
story: Proposals for a new retail development in Inverurie town centre have been submitted to Aberdeenshire Council.Aberdeen-based developer West Coast Estates has been working on the plans with the National Health Service.The development would see the site of the former Inverurie Health Centre transformed into a new retail destination that will complement the existing shops currently available in the town.The proposals, which would see the current building demolished and the vacant town centre site regenerated, would feature four new retail units, including a Starbucks drive thru - the first for the town and only the second of its kind in Aberdeenshire.Developer West Coast Estates say the proposals have been “carefully developed to respect neighbouring properties, utilise its fantastic location and add to the unique character of the town”.West Coast Estates director Iftikar Mian said: “The proposal presents an excellent opportunity to breathe new le into a vacant site in a key location in the town, one that will benefit local residents, and importantly, complement the existing retail offer that is avaialble in Inverurie.“Importantly, and recognising the current need for additional car parking spaces within the town centre, the proposals would also deliver  much needed new car parking spaces.“Discussions are already underway with a iety of operators, including Starbucks, and we look forward to working with the local community, neighbouring businesses, and all those who have an interest in the proposals.”The development would see a total investment of £ million.It is also estimated that it would create up to  full and part-time job opportunities.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: the burning issue is biomass energy as green as it appears
story: The number of Scottish power plants burning trees or plant material to generate renewable energy has quadrupled since . The energy produced is enough to power an estimated , homes, but environmentalists claim biomass energy isn’t as green as it appears.Scotlands biomass sites generate enough energy to power , homes.When people think of clean energy, wind turbines and solar  often come to mind.But biomass power plants – a less well-known method of generating renewable electricity – are booming across the UK and environmental campaigners have raised doubts about their green credentials.The burning of trees or plant matter – known as plant biomass – now accounts for more than a fth of the UK’s renewable energy, second only to wind power.The number of plant biomass power plants in the UK has more than trebled in four years, from  in  to  in .Between them, they now produce enough energy to power around . million homes, analysis by the JPIMedia Data Unit has found.In Scotland, the number has quadrupled from  biomass sites in  to  by . Unlike other forms of green energy, biomass plants produce greenhouse gases. Across the country, the rise in biomass means its total greenhouse gas emissions have nearly reached the amount produced by coal. The industry says wood is sourced from renewable forests, with new trees being planted which store carbon and help to offset the emissions produced.But with the environment proving a key policy battleground in this year’s General Election, campaigners are calling for the practice to come under more scrutiny.Katja Garson, forest and climate campaigner at European campaign group Fern, said: “It is very concerning that in the global push to reduce emissions, more is not being said about the climate impacts of harvesting and burning wood.” Critics have also raised concerns that some power plants ship wood in from overseas, saying this has an added impact on the environment.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fraserburghherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Controversial baby names." Most comes from the USA and Canada, data from the Office for National Statistics shows.Campaigners are also urging the Government to rethink the £. billion in annual subsidies that the biomass industry gets.Almuth Ernsting, of the pressure group Biofuelwatch, said the Government should redirect subsidies to “genuinely low-carbon renewable energy” instead.“For the climate, electricity from forest biomass is no better than electricity from coal,” she said. “Both are completely incompatible with the need to rapidly reduce carbon emissions.”However, Benedict McAleenan, senior advisor to the Renewable Energy Association, said: “Pretending that biomass is somehow no better than coal means ignoring a whole host of facts. “It particularly misunderstands the way forestry works, ignores the important role of regulations and forgets the fact that trees are being regrown all the time.“In reality, UK rules are world-leading and prevent unsustainable practices.”Mr McAleenan said technology being developed called Carbon Capture and Storage would allow biomass plants to “suck carbon out of the atmosphere”, reducing the emissions they produce.He said it would not be possible for the UK to hit net zero-carbon without using bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage.Scotland’s carbon reduction ambitions came a step closer with ground-breaking new charter signed by Government and industry last week. A new alliance of industry, academics and Government officially launched Scotland’s programme to deliver the country’s programme of industrial decarbonisation through the deployment of the UK’s first carbon capture, usage and storagetechnology. The industry led coalition, known as NECCUS, will be instrumental in driving forward the development of CCUS which is recognised as essentialScotland is to meet its target of reducing the country’s carbon emissions to net zero by . CCUS is becoming increasingly commonplace around the world as a way of mitigating climate change. At its simplest, the technology involves capturing the carbon that is emitted from power plantsor energy intensive industries such as chemical and steel producers and then storing the greenhouse gas safely and permanently in rock formations deep below the seabed. Scotland’s project will take this technique further by creating hydrogen which can be used as an alternative to high carbon fuels such as coal, oil and gas for heat and power. CCUS coupled with hydrogen production alongside renewable energy and reforestation – as well as more sustainable production of food and consumer goods – is seen as an essential component of Scotland’s carbon emission reduction target five years before the rest of the UK.The first CCUS plant is expected to be operational by .Mike Smith, NECCUS CEO, said: “We’ve made great progress with wind, solar and other renewable technologies over the last  years. “But the need to decarbonise our economy is urgent so we must build on the good start the UK has made by addressing the hard to decarbonise sectors like heat, heavy industry, transport, and chemicals. “The only way we can achieve that is with the deployment of CCUS. NECCUS, with its unrivalled support from all sectors of industry, academia and Government is now set to deliver on doing just that.”

title: gearing up for the orkney nature festival
story: Spring may seem a long way off, but that hasn#t deterred RSPB Scotland from announcing the dates of their Spring time nature festival.The eighth Orkney Nature Festival will take place from May  to , , and will be embracing a marine theme it was announced last week.  The festival, popular with Orkney locals and visitors alike, is an annual celebration of the unique wildle and natural heritage of the county with events across the Mainland and islands. The programme is made up of a iety of nature-themed events run by local organisations and iniduals and co-ordinated each year by the local RSPB Scotland team.“The Nature Festival is a fantastic opportunity for people to learn more about the special wildle of Orkney, take part in activities, and maybe even discover an island they’ve not visited before,# said RSPB Scotland’s events and communications officer for Orkney, Eleanor Davison.# being the Visit Scotland Year of Coasts and Waters certainly works well for Orkney and we look forward to providing even more coastal-themed events and activities than usual!”The festival is a chance for the people of Orkney to showcase and celebrate the natural wonders that Orkney has to offer and for local businesses to raise awareness of what they do, and so RSPB Scotland are keen for folk to get involved.“We know many people plan trips to Orkney each year to coincide with the festival week, and we aim to provide a range of events, activities and new experiences for all,# added Eleanor.#We are keen to highlight Orkney’s spectacular wildle and get people interacting with nature. With growing awareness of the huge threats facing wildle and habitats in the UK and across the world, it would be great to have more festival events which focus on the importance of looking after our environment and give people the opportunity to get involved on a local level to help save nature.#I would like to encourage anyone who has an idea for an event they would like to run to get in touch as soon as possible.”Any organisation or inidual who would like to take part in the  festival can contact Eleanor at the RSPB Orkney office in Stromness on  or email orkney@rspb.org.uk  For more information on the festival as it becomes available you can check out the website at: www.orkneynaturefestival.orgOr visit the festival#s Facebook page at: www.facebook OrkneyNatureFestivalcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: proxy and postal votes
story: newsProxy and postal votesNovember ,  at : pmVoters in Orkney are being reminded that they still have time to apply for a proxy vote, and to get in their postal votes.Proxy votes enable people who will be away at the time of the General Election, December , to nominate someone to vote on their behalf. The final deadline for proxy vote applications is pm on Wednesday, December .To apply to vote by proxy, Orkney residents should contact the Electoral Registration Office at  Broad Street, Kirkwall, phone  or send an email to ero@orkney.gov.ukMeanwhile, voting packs for the December election have started to be delivered through local letterboxes for people who have opted to vote by post.Postal Vote Packs contain three items — a ballot paper, aenvelope and a postal voting statement attached to a ballot paper envelope.Voters should take time to ensure that they have completed the postal voting statement correctly, making sure that they have signed the statement and filled in the box for their date of birth.When posting their votes, people are encouraged to allow plenty of time for these to reach the Council Offices in Kirkwall on election day. Postal votes can also be handed into polling stations and the Council Offices on the day of the election up until .pm.The UK Parliamentary General Election takes place on Thursday, December , with polling stations open between .am and .pm.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
